text: , also romanized as Ō-an, was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Jōji and before Eiwa. This period started in February 1368 and ended in February 1375.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Ō-an" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 731. The pretenders in Kyoto were Nussbaum, "Go-Kōgon Tennō," p. 255. and Nussbaum, "Go-En'yū Tennō," p. 251; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 310-312. The Southern Court rivals in Yoshino during this time were and .Nussbaum, "Chōkei Tennō," p. 120. ==Events of the Ōan era == * 29 March 1368 (Ōan 1, 21st day of the 2nd month): Emperor Go-Murakami died;Ponsonby- Fane, Richard. (1959). The Imperial House of Japan, p. 138; Kunaichō, 後村上天皇 (97); retrieved 2012-10-2. and his oldest son received the succession.Titsingh, p. 310; Varley, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Kunaichō, Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no-Rei); retrieved 2012-6-29. * 1370 (Ōan 3): Imagawa Sadayo sent to subdue Kyūshū.Ackroyd, Joyce. (1982) Lessons from History: The "Tokushi Yoron", p. 329. * 1373-1406 (Ōan 6 - Ōei 13): Embassies between China and Japan. * 1374 (Ōan 7): En'yū became the head of the Northern Court. ==Southern Court nengō== * Shōhei, 1346–1370 * Kentoku, 1370–1372 * Bunchū, 1372–1375 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Ōan 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 1368 1369 1370 1371 1372 1373 1374 1375 Preceded by: Jōji Northern Court nengō: Ōan Succeeded by: Eiwa Category:Japanese eras Category:1360s establishments in Japan Category:1375 disestablishments Category:1370s disestablishments in Japan
